description.narrative: Promoting Sustainable Employments IV and Supporting the Government in the implementation of the Operational Plan for Labour Market Services and Active Employment Programmes and Measures for 2015

description.narrative: policy, planning and administration

provider-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO
GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative:
1. Number of start-ups supported % of women employed % of young people (aged up to 29) employed % of Roma employed % of start-ups established by people with disabilities
2. Number of participants who completed the training on business plans development
3. Number of additional jobs created in successful small companies % of young staff (aged up to 29) employed % women employed % of supported initiatives that will enable the development of innovative solutions
4. Number of active Youth Info Clubs;
5. Number of downloads of PRV.mk mobile application and number of PRV.MK website visitors
6. Number of individuals at risk of social exclusion who received support through the Community Works Programme % of young people (aged up to 29) who received support through the Community Works Programme % of increase in the number of end beneficiaries (recipients of social services) of the Community Works Programme
7. Number of participants who attended the training on providing professional services to the elderly and obtained a certificate/ license, as part of the Community Works Programme
8. Number of companies supported with a concrete plan for enhanced marketing and presentation of products and services
9. Number of tools developed and provided for local partners to improve monitoring and real time reporting on Employment Programmes' results
10. Number of sector-specific and/or local/regional skills needs assessment studies conducted and curriculum design supported in sectors with high employment opportunities for the disadvantaged;
11. A model and procedures for training provision to people facing social exclusion developed

comment.narrative:
1. The SME sector is facing difficulties in terms of growth and new jobs generation. Since 2007, the Employment Generation Programme helped create over 6,700 new start-ups. 36% of the newly created start-ups are being run by women and 28.4% by young people Self-employment measure targeting people with disabilities has been implemented for the first time in the country by UNDP
2. Since 2007. over 8,300 people have acquired entrepreneurship skills by attending trainings organized by UNDP supported projects
3. Micro and small enterprises (MSEs) limited in their ability to grow and thus hire more workers. In 2014, 82 micro and small companies received help to expand their business, creating additional 119 jobs. Since 2007, 306 MSEs have been supported and 446 new long-term jobs have been created.
4. The activity rate among young people aged 15-24 is extremely low, i.e. 30.6%, which is almost one third of that of persons aged 25-49 (80.1% in Q42014). 4 Youth Info Clubs at four technical faculties have been opened in the country in 2014.
5. 1,530 active users of PRV.mk; 6,500 application downloads; over 1,5 million web site visitors
6. In the period from 2012 to 2014, 220 unemployed people got 6 months short-term employment. In average, 70% of them are women and app. 40% are youth (aged up to 29 years);
7. N/A
8. Lack of supporting activities in the area of marketing and promotion to help the growth of micro and small companies
9. National partners need to enhance their capacity for providing e-services to registered unemployed persons
10. National partners need to improve their capacities for more active cooperation with the private sector and its direct involvement in local level labour market analyses
11. The Adult Education Centre is still not fully operational; institutions' responsibilities are not yet clearly defined, there is lack of coordination between different institutions; There are no procedures for the implementation of educational activitie

1. Provide technical assistance and advice in the process of designing the National Employment Strategy and follow-up programmes that accelerate employment and quality jobs creation for all; 900 self-employments/small businesses established and 60 additional created - 30% young people aged up to 29 - 38% women - 20 Roma - 120 companies established by persons with disability (2016)
2. Strengthening entrepreneurship and management capacities of 1,500 unemployed people in business planning and financial management; Additional 150 people with disabilities will receive training on business management. Barriers and risks and mentoring services will be provided to those that will establish a business during the first year (2016)
3. Up to 200 additional jobs supported in the previously established companies
4. 5 Youth Info Clubs supported in university centers throughout the country
5. Number of young people who use the mobile application PRV.MK
6. Support the establishment of local partnerships for provision of social services to vulnerable groups that will create part-time employment for 300 hard to employ job-seekers.
7. Training of 50 people to provide professional services to the elderly through the Community Works Programme

1. 942 people received coaching, training and small grants to start their own business. 35% of these new entrepreneurs are women and 29% are young people aged up to 29. Out of the 12 unemployed Roma who successfully completed the Self-Employment Programme, 9 started their new businesses.
2. 1,332 unemployed candidates underwent a training for strengthening their entrepreneurship and management skills and 1,256 obtained a certificate for successfully completing the training.
3. 72 micro and small companies received help to expand their businesses, creating another 111 jobs.
4. Contracts with 4 Youth Info Clubs were extended in 4 university centers. 1,732 students obtained information about job opportunities. The architectural design of the fifth Youth Info Club is developed and ready to be implemented in 2016 once a mutual agreement with the Faculty of Mechanical Engineering is reached.
5. PRV.mk is a smart application that brings the latest job openings directly to a mobile phone, including internships and volunteer positions. The app is functional for three mobile operating systems (Android, iOS and Windows Phone). Over 7,100 downloads and around 1,400 active users are registered by Play Store (Android). A new, advanced version of PRV.mk 2.0 has been introduced to all users, which will bring the latest news, tips and hints and other opportunities closer to young people.
6. The Community Works Programme supported 42 municipalities in tackling social exclusion on two fronts at once. Implemented by the Government, municipalities and UNDP, the Programme offered opportunities to 318 unemployed people to gain valuable skills while also providing social services to the most socially excluded groups in the country. Out of the 318 beneficiaries, 43% are young unemployed, aged up to 29. Over 10,000 socially excluded people in 42 municipalities have felt the benefits from the services provided through the Programme, with each municipality launching schemes of part-t

description.narrative: Local Action for Inclusive Development

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: This is a preparatory assistance project. The overall objective of this project is to intensify integrated local and regional development of the country by providing assistance for enhancement of the local inclusive community based development framework.

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: independent political entity
Accountability - local government finance

provider-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO
GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: Number of specific assessments. Number of knowledge transfer tools, including tailor made training modules and number of trainees. Number of action plans addressing immediate needs of local stakeholders. Number of ICT interventions that enable open access to user-friendly information on local public expenditures. Number of social audits of local services and public expenditures performed. Number of partnerships between civil society organizations and public entities established. Number of Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms established. Number of services and policy products produced and delivered by the established Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms. Number of social entrepreneurship partnerships of Civil Society Organization and public and private entities. Number of local Commissions for Equal Opportunities that operate more frequently, effectively and efficiently. Number of recommendations for a local and regional policy action on climate change mitigation and adaptation.

comment.narrative: Limited local/planning region institutional capacities for inclusive governance and community based local and regional development. Limited funds for implementation of the Capacity Development Programme and Action Plan for improvement of the integrated local/planning region governance system of the Vardar Planning Region. Lack of comprehensive reporting on the financing of local services and limited access to user-friendly information on local public expenditures. Limited use of IT and social media for delivery of local services. Lack of regional and local funds to support operations and scaling up of the existing Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and establishment of new Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and social partnerships in the Vardar Planning region Lack of state incentives for establishment and functioning of Inter-Municipal Cooperation and social partnerships. The Ministry of Local Self-Government did not start updating and maintaining the established Inter-Municipal Cooperation knowledge management system and the E-evidence of established Inter-Municipal Cooperation forms and forms of international cooperation of the municipalities. Limited information on the needs of the vulnerable segments of the local communities related to their participation in local/regional governance processes. Local Commissions for Equal Opportunities do not operate frequently, effectively and efficiently. Lack of performance indicators to monitor and evaluate the progress in addressing the vulnerabilities as well as the quality of the most critical local services. Limited number of partnerships of the local/regional authorities with the private sector and civil society. Lack of social entrepreneurship initiatives and programmes. Limited bottom up generated evidence and efforts for down-streaming the programming of the local economic development and regional competitiveness as well as the agriculture and rural development in accordance with the respective chapters of the EU

A report analyzing municipal revenues and expenditures for 2014/2015 was prepared to collect data on the trends regarding the financing of municipalities and enable corrective actions.. Guidance and support for the implementation of one priority action from the 2014 – 2016 Programme of the Network for Inclusive Development of the Vardar Planning Region provided. Inter-municipal cooperation for provision of care to vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman and r addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities established, to enable economy of scale and delivery of new and innovative local services An elevator for people with disabilities purchased and installed in the seat of the municipality of Kavadarci and another elevator for children with disabilities purchased and installed in one elementary school in the municipality of Veles to demonstrate solutions for overcoming physical barriers and increasing the mobility of the people with disabilities Recreational equipment for people with disabilities purchased and installed in one recreational site in each of the Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman municipalities to create better conditions for recreation of people with disabilities.

The Reports analyzing municipal revenues and expenditures for 2014/ and the first half of 2015 were prepared. Organization of the third “Partners Day” in the Vardar Planning region was supported – the event will be held in the forst quarter of 2016 Inter-municipal cooperation for provision of care to vulnerable groups in the municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Gradsko, Chaska and Rosoman and for addressing the priority needs of people with disabilities was established. Elevator for pupils with disabilities was purchased and installed in one primary school in Veles. In addition a lavatory in the school was refurbished. In the frame of the campaign to raise public awareness about people with special needs and disabilities a one-day visit to the St. Georgia monastery in Negotino was organized for more than 70 people with special needs and disabilities of all ages by the NGO - Association of people with cerebral paralyses – Veles. Equipment for exercise of persons with special needs and disabilities were purchased and installed in Veles Youth Park and Kavadarci Park. Construction of gazebos for people with disabilities and landscaping of the area around them in municipalities of Veles, Kavadarci, Rosoman, Cashka and Gradsko was completed.

description.narrative: Promoting greater civic engagement for young people at local level
Promoting greater civic engagement for young people at local level
independent political entity
Other General Services - support to civil society

1. Number of youth organizations participating in the development of the National Youth Strategy 2. Number of Local Youth Councils participating in the development of the National Youth Strategy 3. Number of activities and events organized on social cohesion among youth 4. Number of events on youth participation in decision-making 5. Number of staff in central and local government in charge of responding to youth questions and queries 6. Regulation of youth work initiated, developed and adopted

comment.narrative: 1. Lack of interest among stakeholders to involve youth in policy making and lack of systemic mechanisms to ensure youth participation in decision making 2.Lack of innovative tools to increase youth informing 3.Lack of youth involvement in promotion of SDG/post 2015 agenda 4. Low level of engagement of vulnerable youth groups

1. At least 60 youth organizations and informal groups actively participate in the process for development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 2. At least 6 local youth councils actively participate in the process for development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 3. At least 50 events/workshops are organized on youth participation in decision making 4. A new National Youth Strategy is adopted by the Government (by December 2015) 5. A National Action Plan for the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2020) is developed 6. At least 20 different activities to support social cohesion among youth in multi-ethnic societies are organized, with provision of direct support and capacity building of local youth councils and local youth CSOs.

1. Over 95 youth organizations and informal groups actively involved in the development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 2. 11 local youth councils actively participated in the development of the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2025) 3. 65 workshops, public debates, local meetings and discussions were organized on youth participation in decision making 4. Draft National Youth Strategy submitted for adoption to the Government 5. Draft 5 year Action Plan for the new National Youth Strategy (2016-2020) developed 6. 30 workshops, trainings, street art performances and debates held, specifically aimed at supporting social cohesion among youth in multi-ethnic societies. Trainings provided direct support and capacity building of local youth councils and local youth CSOs.

description.narrative: This initiation plan aims to create a youth-friendly space for inclusive dialogue in Kumanovo that will serve as a platform for youth-driven activities that satisfy substantive local needs while bringing a diverse community together.
Other General Services - support to civil society

Output 1: Establishment of a Youth Facility as an intercultural learning and communication platform for sustainable inter-ethnic dialogue and social cohesion
Indicators: • Number of workshops organized to promote social cohesion /human rights issues • Number of people covered in social cohesion activities (disaggregated by sex) • Number of women empowered
Output 2: Women’s Section created (specifically for women and girls from minority groups) within the Youth Facility for discussing topics of interest particularly related to security and safety
Indicators: • Number of initiatives organized to promote the role of women and girls in promoting social cohesion • Number of initiatives developed and executed by women • Number of active young women in the Women’s corner
Output 3: Youth volunteer groups addressing migrant issues through support to local services and community mobilization/ awareness raising
Indicators: • Number of active participants in youth volunteer groups (disaggregated by sex ) • Number of awareness raising activities implemented relating to migrants • Number of community members involved in migrant related activities • Number of local services relating to support to municipality to address migrant needs
Output 4: Knowledge kits created on the issues of interest of youth (human rights, social cohesion, youth participation and gender) shared nationally
Indicators:
• Number of active users of the new online platform (disaggregated by sex ) • Number of local youth organizations using the new knowledge kit • Number of municipalities trained/informed of the new toolkit

comment.narrative:
Output 1: Establishment of a Youth Facility as an intercultural learning and communication platform for sustainable inter-ethnic dialogue and social cohesion
Baseline: Lack of data on youth needs in cross cultural settings Low level of activities promoting social cohesion/human rights Lack of meaningful activities led by women promoting social cohesion
Output 2: Women’s Section created (specifically for women and girls from minority groups) within the Youth Facility for discussing topics of interest particularly related to security and safety
Baseline: Lack of women’s empowerment initiatives Low level of women in leadership roles
Output 3: Youth volunteer groups addressing migrant issues through support to local services and community mobilization/ awareness raising
Baseline: Lack of cooperation and cross-ethnic initiatives among youth from different ethnic groups Lack of youth inclusion in local service delivery
Output 4: Knowledge kits created on the issues of interest of youth (human rights, social cohesion, youth participation and gender) shared nationally
Baseline: No integrated and innovative tools for learning and participation of youth in social cohesion issues

description.narrative: Restoration of the Prespa Lake Ecosystem
Contribution to the improvement of the Prespa Lake’s Ecological State and its Resilience
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

At least 8% reduction of nutrient loads (and other substances) to the lake as a result of the gradual increase of project supported measures % of hectares under Good Agricultural Practices and/or agro-ecological measures $ of area under nature-based systems (wetlands, river corridors, buffers) Quantity of collected pesticide packaging and biodegradable waste Functional Watershed Management Committee as a formal cross-sectoral participatory mechanism for integrated watershed management # of knowledge products (manuals, guidance documents, lessons learnt booklets, fact sheets and articles)

comment.narrative: High proportion of the delineated water bodies in the Prespa Lake watershed doesn’t meet the requirement of having ‘good’ ecological status according to the existing regulations Important natural landscape elements (ecotones) are being destroyed over the past decades as a result of development pressures The current nutrient loads of anthropogenic origin (500 t/year) exceed the levels the lake ecosystem can absorb without further degrading Unsustainable farming practices, especially overuse of pesticides, fertilizers and irrigation water No sufficient monitoring and management capacities exist at present The current organizational structure and capacity of Municipality of Resen and other responsible organizations / institutions doesn’t meet the needs of an integrated watershed management system Low level of awareness about nature protection and sustainable use of natural resources

Completion of Phase 2 of the Eutrophication study: Model development and application of alternative management scenarios Implementation of the 2 cycle of agro-ecological farming practices measures in Prespa and inclusion of at least 40 new farmers in the grant scheme (at least 5 of them female). Final decision on the scope of wetland restoration reached and start of implementation of the wetland restoration alternative Implementation of Priority erosion control measures implemented on an area of at least 40 ha of forest land Implementation of at least 10 community driven small-scale infrastructure projects Regular monitoring reports generated by the Lake Monitoring Station

The Eutrophication study: Model development and application of alternative management scenarios completed Implementation of the 2 cycle of agro-ecological farming practices measures in Prespa successfully completed with inclusion of total 77 farmers in two cycles, out of which 10 female farmers Alternative solutions for implementation of the wetland restoration elaborated and decision on the final solution of wetland restoration reached Priority erosion control measures implemented on an area of 40 ha of forest land 10 community driven small-scale infrastructure projects (reconstruction of water supply and sewage collection systems, small eco-parks in two villages, etc) implemented in the municipality of Resen The Lake Monitoring Station in Stenje fully operational and regularly generates monitoring reports for the Prespa Lake

title.narrative: Macedonian Biennial GHG Emissions Update Report

description.narrative: The immediate objective of the project is to assist the country in the preparation and submission of its First Biennial Update Report to the Conference of the Parties to the UNFCCC.

title.narrative: Macedonian Biennial GHG Emissions Update Report

description.narrative: To assist the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in the preparation of its First Biennial Update Report (FBUR) for the fullfilment of the obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

• National circumstances and institutional arrangements relevant to the preparation of the national communications updated • Updated GHG inventory • Continuous data measurement and analysis system established • Number of studies available to inform different institutions and sectors about feasible mitigation policies and measures and their potential prioritization to facilitate decision making • Upgraded mitigation chapter in the FBUR • Technology, financial and capacity needs for mitigation assessment. • A case study for mitigation potential - switching from conventional fuel to natural gas, showing the economic and environmental benefits • Information on national resources allocated for climate change upon ratification of the UNFCCC • Relevant training curricula and number of trained individuals • Options for establishment of a domestic MRV system analyzed • Process for establishment of national institutional and legal frameworks for domestic MRV initiated.

comment.narrative: • Initial and Second National Communications on climate change endorsed and submitted to UNFCCC, Third National Communication under development • Outline of the national circumstances as part of the TNC (2013) • Inventories for the period 1990 – 2009 revised • Sectoral studies/reports for the mitigation potential in the respective sectors • Mitigation scenarios as part of the TNC • Technology, financial and capacity needs for mitigation report as part of the TNC. • Initial analyses done and a roadmap for MRV developed

First Biennial Update Report adopted by the Government and submitted to UNFCCC;
Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) adopted by the Government and timely submitted to the UNFCCCC

The First Biennial Update Report adopted by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCC in February 2015;
The Intended Nationally Determined Contributions (INDCs) adopted by the Government and submitted to the UNFCCCC in August 2015, prior to the 21st CoP in Paris

title.narrative: Innovative Solutions for Improved Access to Services

description.narrative: The main objective of the project is to enable the MLSG as a coordinator and monitor of the issues related to decentralization and local governance to further advance its efforts in promoting the citizen oriented local governance.

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

title.narrative: Innovative Solutions for Improved Access to Services
Innovative Solutions for Improved Access to Services
Innovative Solutions for Improved Access to Services
Innovative Solutions for Improved Access to Services

description.narrative: Innovative solutions for improved access to services at local level

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: Accountability - local government finance

provider-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO
GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: Comprehensive citizens’ satisfaction survey designed and implemented. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the survey results. Crosscutting analyses prepared and decentralization strategic framework adjusted. A partnership programme designed and implemented. Local e-services study prepared. At least one consultative event organized to discuss the results. Local e-services road-map prepared. In-depth analysis of the existing Inter –Municipal Cooperation practices and the current Inter –Municipal Cooperation policies presented to the Government. Best Inter –Municipal Cooperation practice award established and at least two Inter –Municipal Cooperation arrangements supported. Assessment report on the possibility to establish a Unit for Support of Private Enterprises within the Centers for Regional Development, prepared. New Decentralization Programme for the period 2015 – 2020, prepared.

comment.narrative: No updated data and analyses of citizens’ perceptions on the quality of local services, resulting in policies and actions that do not reflect citizens’ priority needs. Lack of innovative partnership programme to address service delivery. No updated and sufficient data and analyses of existing local e-services and related needs and opportunities. Inter –Municipal Cooperation evidence system established. Mid-term decentralization policy review completed. Lack of state financial support for Inter –Municipal Cooperation, resulting in insufficient utilization of this tool for alternative service delivery. Centers for development of the planning regions face serious sustainability issues due to an inappropriate financing system. The existing decentralization programme expires in 2014, which creates a risk for the country to remain without a very important policy for the development of its local self-government system.

The Local e-Services Study finalized and endorsed by the Government to create a basis for the formulation of a new policy for modernization of municipal services The inclusive development networks of the Vardar Pelagonia and Northeast planning regions supported to implement priority actions derived from their Programmes and Action Plans. Technical support provided to the State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission for amending the Law on Inter-Municipal Cooperation and the related policy. The Centers for development of the five planning regions (Skopje, Polog, East, Southwest and Southeast Regions) supported in preparation of Programmes, Action Plans and Communication Strategies of the newly established Business Centers for Support of Small and Medium Enterprises . Implementation of activities for increasing regional competitiveness supported. Transfer of international best practices on distribution of state aid for private sector research and development at regional level and attraction of foreign investments enabled through study trip to the Czech Republic and three workshops with Czech experts in the country. Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 – 2020 finalized and endorsed by the Government and broadly disseminated. 2015 – 2017 Action Plan of the Programme for Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization 2015 – 2020 and Monitoring Methodology prepared and endorsed by the Government. Third Annual Conference on Sustainable Local Development and Decentralization, organized with the aim to gather all relevant stakeholders in taking stock of the implementation of the decentralization policy in 2015 and formulating joint recommendations and prioritizing actions for 2016. Potentials for development of forms of rural tourism in the four (4) least developed planning regions in the country (Northeast, Vardar, Southwest and Polog) mapped and rural tourism registers prepared, thus creating basis for more accurate preparation

The final Draft of an Integrated Study on Local e-Services was discussed and endorsed by the Government Committee on e-Services. Integrated Regional Development Network (IRDN) was formed in the Pelagonia Planning Region, and the Platform for Regional Rural Action (PRRA) was established in the Northeast Planning Region. Both Networks prepared Programmes of Work and respective Action Plans and started with the implementation of priority activities. Premises where both Networks operate were refurbished. The Vardar Region Inclusive Network continued with implementation of the 2013 – 2015 Programme of work. Center for Development of Pelagonija Planning Region held 2 promotional events for increasing capacities of the business sector (one workshop on agricultural business and the other workshop on utilization of domestic and foreign financial instruments, organized with the Regional Chamber of Commerce). Centre for Development of Vardar Planning Region held the event for promotion of the three products: the Guide for investors, the Map/Collection of the Industrial Zones and the web portal. The economic operator presented the products before the mayors, as well as representatives of business and civil sector. Based on a pre-prepared analysis of existing practices and current Inter-Municipal Cooperation (IMC), a Draft Law amending the Law on IMC was prepared. The State Inter-Municipal Cooperation Commission was assisted in preparation of the 2015 IMC Status Report. The brochure Inter-Municipal Cooperation in the Republic of Macedonia was published.
Programs for Private Sector Support, including an Action Plan and Communication Plan for Program Implementation were prepared by the Business Centers established for support and advisory services to SMEs in Skopje, Polog, East, Southeast and Southwest Planning Regions. In all 5 Centers, altogether 28 informational events were organized and attended by a total of 1053 participants (586 men and 467 women), most of whom were repre

description.narrative: This project focus on boosting the local development through improved local revenue capacity and accountable local public expenditures and starts with preparatory assistance/project initation plan.

title.narrative: Initiation Plan - Empowering Municipal Councils Project

description.narrative: This is a preparatory assistance project/initiation plan project focused on boosting the local development through improved local revenue capacity and accountable local public expenditures.
Accountability - local government finance

Drivers and restrainers of reform change as anticipated by the project description, identified. Participatory programme development process involving key stakeholders from all 81 local self-government units in order to elaborate the programme, initiated. Project Document, elaborated including detailed analysis of each of the proposed interventions on national, and local level, with annexes like log-frame, time schedule (sequencing of components), budget, required resources: personnel, technology, know how. Impact hypothesis and result chains, including outcomes, outputs, activities, and a cost benefit and cost effectiveness analysis of the programme intervention, elaborated as integral part of the Project Document. Programme organization, tasks and responsibilities of all stakeholders steering mechanisms, monitoring system, defined. Risk management: assessment of opportunities, risks and mitigation strategies, defined. Strategy for improving sustainability and opportunities for up scaling, including exit strategy, formulated. Suitable actions for citizen participation in the budgeting processes at municipal level, identified. Tools/manner for cooperation and collaboration with the local implementing partner organization, defined. Indicators for the selection of the municipalities with the most capacity and will to address the need for better knowledge of the municipal councilors about their role and the professional execution of tasks by the municipal administration, developed. Training and capacity building curriculum for the municipal councilors and municipal administration to improve their knowledge of the budgeting process and to increase their accountability towards the citizens in line with the methodology presented in the offer, namely the concept of small wins and avoiding push back, developed and tested in 6-8 municipalities. Cooperation e with the important actors such as the Ministry of Finance, ZELS and international donors active in the same field of c

comment.narrative: Municipal councils often fail to fully perform their functions of oversight, representation and legislation. Strong influence of the party centers strengthened by the lack of local fiscal independence, payment as a perverse incentive for being a council member, underdeveloped networking among the councils, and a lack of demand for accountability from the side of the citizens. Most municipal councils (with a few exceptions) have become voting machines for backing up or opposing the mayor’s decisions. The majority of municipal councilors remain anonymous in the public eye and even within the local governance circles. The National Association of the Municipalities, once a two-chamber body, is now dominated by the mayors. Insufficient education and awareness of councilors for execution of their mandate Disturbed interaction between the executive (mayor and administration) and the decision-making (councils) bodies. Only about 20% of the surveyed councils in 2013 reported that they have initiated citizens’ gatherings or public hearings, and recognize that citizen participation is not at a satisfactory level. Less than 10 councils reported discussing their development programmes with their communities. Only 9 councils reported that they have ever discussed the fiscal gaps between revenues and expenditures, and only 22 of them have discussed debt management issues. Only one council has approved financing of a programme coming from inter-ethnic committee, similar is the situation regarding the council’s committees for consumer protection and gender equality. The Council Finance and Budget committees are the most active, and at least formally they regularly pursue all necessary legal steps for adopting the budgets and the annual accounts.

A situation analysis that will identify all stakeholders, confirm the drivers and restrainers of reform, the “positive” and” negative” outliers, potential allies and partners, carried out. Tools for assessment of the state of the local public finance management, gender and inter-ethnic aspects of the work of the municipal councils and the applied innovation in the local governance process, designed and applied. A participatory project development process with all identified stakeholders from the 81 local self-government units, completed. Tools/manner for cooperation and collaboration with the Association of the Finance Officers, defined and cooperation agreement signed. Indicators for the selection of the municipalities to work with during the second – implementation phase of the project, developed. Training and capacity building curriculum for the municipal councilors and municipal administration, developed and tested in 6-8 municipalities. The Project Board established.

Stakeholders map was prepared and seventeen (17) consultation and situation analyses events with relevant stakeholders were organized. The project objectives and implementation strategy were communicated to a total of 432 participants coming from 76 municipalities, the Ministry of Finance [MoF], the ZELS, and the Ministry of Local Self-Government [MLSG]. Basic Financial, Capacity Needs, Governance and Gender and Inter-ethnic Assessments including respective assessment tools were designed and their implementation was initiated. Participatory project document preparation process was initiated and the expectations of the local stakeholders against the initial project assumptions were validated. Cooperation agreement was concluded with the Association of the Finance Officers. The assessment tools (questionnaires and indicators) in practice will serve as (performance) indicators for selection of the municipalities. The work on the Training and Capacity Building Curriculum for the municipal councilors and municipal administration, was initiated. The Project Board was established.

description.narrative: Preparation of Watershed Management Plan for Restoration of Strumica River
Implementation of the Management Plan for Strumica River Basin
Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: • Launching the development of flood hazard and flood risk maps for the Strumica River Basin • Launching the programme to improve pollution prevention and control through strengthening permitting and enforcement capacities • Start of process for identification of most feasible basin-scale wastewater management options • Launching of a technical assistance framework for introduction of agro-ecological farming practices for priority crops in the Basin • Upgrade of the water quality monitoring database for the key water bodies in the Basin

description.narrative: Increasing Urban Resilience by use of ICT for Mainstreaming Disaster and Climate Risk Reduction in Armenia, FYR Macedonia and Moldova

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: Build disaster and climate resilience in the three participating countries by increasing institutional capacity, mobilizing knowledge and transferring appropriate best-practice innovation technologies.

participating-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Build disaster and climate resilience by increasing institutional capacity, mobilizing knowledge and transferring appropriate best practice innovation technologies

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

provider-org.narrative: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO
GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA, THE FORMER YUGO

description.narrative: Urban resilience action plan and climate change strategy for the City of Skopje in place. Gender considerations incorporated in the urban disaster and climate resilience action plans. # of targeted capacity strengthening programmes implemented. # of replications and scaling up of the existing mobile disaster risk reduction and climate change application # of ICT solutions for information sharing/public awareness raising on urban resilience, including solutions that take into consideration the needs of vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

comment.narrative: Lack of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience action plans in the country. Insufficient technical knowledge and expertise for preparation of integrated urban disaster and climate resilience plans. Ad-hoc integration of disaster and climate change issues into national policies and strategies. Low public awareness on urban resilience on disaster and climate risks. Low level of cooperation and information sharing between different level of stakeholders and organizations dealing with disastwer risk reduction; Poor integration of ICT led disaster risk reduction solutions for vulnerable categories of citizens, especially disabled persons.

Draft Integrated Urban Resilience Action Plans for the City of Skopje developed with participation of men and women. Two targeted capacity strengthening programme for the key stakeholders implemented Inventory of Greenhouse gasses for City of Skopje as per the 2006 IPCC guidelines for two years (2008 and 2012) developed - database and narrative report. Stakeholder map with indicated key stakeholders and information flows developed. 10 local thematic groups for identification of priority vulnerable sectors established as a consultative mechanism for development of a Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje. Draft Climate Change Strategy for City of Skopje developed. Rapid Assessment of the current situation and needs for ICT for Urban Resilience conducted. Mobile DRR applications replication/scaling up initiated in the participating countries.

Inventory of Greenhouse gasses for City of Skopje as per the 2006 IPCC guidelines for two years (2008 and 2012) and mitigation narrative report developed. 15 foresight based stakeholder workshops to identify the vulnerable sectors and priorities for preparation of the strategy carried, 290 persons participated at the workshops ranging from high schools, municipal representatives, city administration and representatives from national institutions on local level. The key priorities and vulnerable sectors for development of the Climate Change Strategy for the City of Skopje and the action plan were identified. Rapid Assessment of the current situation and needs for ICT for Urban Resilience conducted.Analysis and recommendations for an integrated spatial platform for urban resilience were done based on the analysis of the existing and planned geo and spatial service and information databases in City of Skopje, and the participating institutions. The system for urban resilience of City of Skopje shall be with SOA (Service Oriented Architecture) and shall be divided in two parts: WEB GIS platform for urban resilience in City of Skopje and spatial data aggregator hosted in Crisis Management Centre. In MKD a mobile application for safe evacuation with using of QR codes was developed and has “Disaster Buddy” module that send the location and text to three contacts in case of crisis or disasters

description.narrative: Umbrella programme to cover anti-corruption and rule of law activities at central and local levels.

This is an Initiation Plan for the COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMME FOR PROMOTION OF RULE OF LAW, INTEGRITY, TRANSPARENCY AND ACCOUNTABILITY AT CENTRAL AND LOCAL LEVELS” including anti-corruption work and support to rule of law EU accession agenda.
Anti corruption

comment.narrative: -The rule of law agenda of Chapter 23 and 24 of the EU acquis, has been one of the key national priorities where UNDP has managed to provide support to the human and institutional capacity-building through the UNDP Regional Facility in Croatia. Institutions continued to rely on UNDP for supporting the rule of law agenda and the home affairs sector through access of knowledge, experiences and resources. -UNDP has established a long-standing partnership with the State Commission for Prevention of Corruption on policy design processes, but also on offering innovative models, tools and methodologies for addressing corruption risks at local level. -The State Commission for Prevention of Corruption is due to start preparing the new State Anti-Corruption Pagramme 2016-2010 by the end of the year and is need of being exposed to good practices that can be incorporated in the new Programme. - The country has been undergoing a political crisis and corruption has been on the agenda of high level dialogue between the political parties for overcoming the crisis and agreeing on future reforms.

• Sector planning document on home affairs prepared with technical support from UNDP; • Support provided to the relevant anti-corruption bodies and stakeholders on maintaining the dialogue on the lessons learnt from the implementation of the current Anti-Corruption Programme and on avenues and priorities of the next anti-corruption policy reforms. • Good practices and tools on innovation in anti-corruption shared with the relevant anti-corruption bodies, with support from the UNDP Istanbul Regional Hub. • UNDP contribution provided to high level discussions for anti-corruption policy reforms.

• Based on good practices and regional experiences, technical assistance was provided to the Ministry of Internal Affairs for preparation of the sector planning home affairs document, including with support through the expertise from the Regional Facility in Croatia. The final outcome of the process was a mid-term EU home affairs sector planning document which defined priority areas that might be financed under IPA II and prepare the ground for its proper management, monitoring and evaluation.
• At the beginning of the year, UNDP supported the State Anti-Corruption Commission on organizing a debate to reflect on the progress of implementation of the State Programme for Prevention of Corruption. The debate provided space for the relevant stakeholders to discuss the challenges and lessons learnt from the implementation of the current Anti-Corruption Programme and the avenues and priorities for the next anti-corruption policy reforms.
• UNDP’s specific contribution to the anti-corruption dialogue was focused on sharing of best practices on application of innovative approaches and experiences in prevention of corruption at local level in cooperation with the UNDP Regional Hub in Istanbul.
• Acknowledging the complexities pertaining to the current political environment in the country, UNDP continued advocating for transparency, accountability and prevention of corruption, particularly at local level through its other local development/decentralization projects, while offering technical assistance to the high-level political working group on the upcoming anti-corruption policy discussions.

description.narrative: Rehabilitation of infrastructure after floods in the country
The country and its citizens benefit from the reconstructed transport infrastructure, its increased resilience to floods and improved floods mitigation potential
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Number of reconstructed bridges/culverts damaged by the floods (at least 4 in total length of 161,67m)
Number and length of recovered roads by category of road and regions (at least 16 km of local roads in four affected municipalities)
At least one landslide on regional/local roads stabilized
# of Knowledge products and public awareness raising material
Guidance document for incorporation of the “built back better” in place

comment.narrative:
42.8 % of total damages and losses occurred in the infrastructure sector due to the floods that occured in 2015 . Increased risk and vulnerability of transport infrastructure through instability of sloping terrain that may cause further landslides, the occurrence of aftershocks following an earthquake, and possible occurrence of further intensive rainfall and flooding
Limited knowledge about the contemporary approaches for recovery of infrastructure in accordance with the ‘build back better’ principles. The current design approaches often do not take the importance of enhancing resilience of the infrastructure into consideration
Sign of the Project Document with the EU Delegation and initiate activities for the start up of the project
The Project Document with the EU Delegation signed on 20 November and activities to start up da project initiated.

description.narrative: Community Resilience Building
Community Resilience to various types of crisis and disasters
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

title.narrative: Response to the effects of the migrant/refugee crisis

description.narrative: The project will improve the coordination of efforts to respond to the crisis, while at the same time developing a recovery framework based on a comprehensive needs analysis and an action plan for priority activities.

To improve the coordination of efforts to respond to the crisis, while at the same time developing a recovery framework based on a comprehensive needs analysis and an action plan for priority activities.
Accountability - local government finance

Existence of coordinated response Techical assistance provided for high level policy advice Technical assistance provided for unified needs assessment Appropriate technical documentation drafted and adopted and compiled in a comprehensive recovery plan

comment.narrative: Low coordination capacities Lack of high level policy advice No unified needs assessment No technical documentation for recovery activities.
